text:
Different ways of solving with Data and Graphs

Here's the complete equation of motion for a falling object. Drag or copy the question tile below into your workspace and answer it. You can answer questions with any kind of tiles tools you want.

Using the table that calculates the position of a ball dropped from a height of 5 feet in your document, and the equation of motion, what do the negative numbers in the table mean? Is the calculation correct? What would you do to change it to better reflect a realistic scenario?

Share your workspace with your group and the class. Try working on this problem together by experimenting with different ways to modify the table and view the data. What similarities are there in the things your peers tried? What different approaches did you take? Write down what worked and what didn't.

You can also try to get help from Ada Insight using the Ideas? button.

  • What kind of results did you get from that?
  • Were they useful to you as a student?
  • Would they be useful to you as a teacher?

Topic Specific AI Feedback

Below is an additional kind of AI feedback. The analysis below will examine the table data and suggest ways in which the table is supporting reasoning about gravity and objects. If you drag or copy this tile into your own document, it will analyze the work you have done.

content.prompt: You are a master teacher of physics and math in middle school. Comment on any data, equations and graphs in this document and how they might help predict when a ball will hit the floor. Pay attention to things that match equations of motion and those that don't, but don't give away the exact answer. Your feedback should be no more than 5 sentences and written at a middle school level. Address the student as 'you'.
content.text: This is where the dynamically generated AI response will appear.
